literary.text: So engrossed was she that she had no consciousness of being observed, and one emotion after another crept into her face like objects into a slowly developing picture.
paraphrases: She was so absorbed that she remained unaware of being watched, and one emotion after another spread across her face like objects emerging in a slowly developing photograph.
Completely engrossed, she did not realize she was observed, and her features took on successive emotions as if objects were materializing in a gradually forming picture.
So wrapped up in herself, she lost all sense of being watched, while emotion after emotion surfaced on her face just like items appearing in a slowly developing image.

literary.text: The consequence of it is, that Lady Lucas will have a daughter married before I have, and that Longbourn estate is just as much entailed as ever.
paraphrases: As a result, Lady Lucas will see her daughter wed before I do, and the Longbourn estate remains as firmly entailed as ever.
The result is that Lady Lucas’s daughter will be married before mine is, and the Longbourn estate remains as strictly entailed as ever.
Consequently, Lady Lucas will have her daughter married before I do, and the entail on Longbourn remains exactly as before.

literary.text: Day after day passed away without bringing any other tidings of him than the report which shortly prevailed in Meryton of his coming no more to Netherfield the whole winter; a report which highly incensed Mrs. Bennet, and which she never failed to contradict as a most scandalous falsehood.
paraphrases: Day after day slipped by bringing no news of him save for the report in Meryton that he would not return to Netherfield for the entire winter, a rumor that enraged Mrs. Bennet and which she invariably denounced as a most scandalous falsehood.

One day followed another without any tidings of him except the tale circulating in Meryton that he intended to forsake Netherfield all winter, a story that deeply provoked Mrs. Bennet, who unfailingly rejected it as an outrageous lie.

Weeks crept past without any further information about him beyond the whisper in Meryton that he would spend the winter away from Netherfield—a whisper that incensed Mrs. Bennet, leading her to constantly repudiate it as a most egregious untruth.

literary.text: Mr. Collins no sooner saw the two girls than he began to congratulate them on their good fortune, which Charlotte explained by letting them know that the whole party was asked to dine at Rosings the next day.
paraphrases: Hardly had Mr. Collins caught sight of the two girls before he was congratulating them on their good fortune, which Charlotte then clarified by informing them that the entire party had been invited to dine at Rosings the next day.

Immediately upon seeing the two girls, Mr. Collins congratulated them on their luck, a gesture Charlotte elucidated by revealing that the whole party was invited to dinner at Rosings the following day.

No sooner did Mr. Collins set eyes on the two girls than he began praising their good fortune, an explanation Charlotte provided by announcing that the entire party had been asked to dine at Rosings the next day.

literary.text: Where’d you pick that up?” “Now see here, Tom,” said Daisy, turning around from the mirror, “if you’re going to make personal remarks I won’t stay here a minute.
paraphrases: "Where did you learn that?" "Now look here, Tom," Daisy said, turning from the mirror, "if you're going to make personal remarks, I won't stay here another moment."
"How did you pick that up?" "Now listen, Tom," Daisy retorted, pivoting away from the mirror, "if you're going to lob personal comments, I won't remain here for even a second."
"Where on earth did you hear that?" "Now see here, Tom," Daisy exclaimed, spinning away from the mirror, "if you're about to hurl personal insults, I won't stay here a bit longer."

literary.text: Mrs. Bennet sent them word that they could not possibly have the carriage before Tuesday; and in her postscript it was added, that if Mr. Bingley and his sister pressed them to stay longer, she could spare them very well.
paraphrases: Mrs. Bennet informed them that the carriage couldn’t be made available until Tuesday, and in a postscript she noted that if Mr. Bingley and his sister wished to extend their stay, she could easily accommodate them.
Mrs. Bennet wrote to say that the carriage would not arrive before Tuesday, adding in her postscript that she would be quite happy to keep them longer if Mr. Bingley and his sister desired it.

In her letter, Mrs. Bennet explained that they could not possibly have the carriage before Tuesday and added in a postscript that she would readily spare accommodation if Mr. Bingley and his sister pressed to remain longer.

literary.text: Let the other young ladies have time to exhibit.” Mary, though pretending not to hear, was somewhat disconcerted; and Elizabeth, sorry for her, and sorry for her father’s speech, was afraid her anxiety had done no good.
paraphrases: “Allow the other young ladies a chance to display their accomplishments,” he observed, and Mary, though pretending not to hear, felt a flicker of discomfort; Elizabeth, sympathizing with her and troubled by her father’s words, feared her own anxiety had been in vain.

“Give the other young ladies some time to present themselves,” he said, and Mary, acting oblivious, was nevertheless unsettled; Elizabeth, pitying her and mortified by her father’s remark, worried that her concern had yielded nothing.

“Let the remaining young ladies show their merits,” he declared, and Mary, feigning deafness, experienced a moment of unease; Elizabeth, full of compassion for her and regretful of her father’s bluntness, was afraid her anxiousness had been pointless.

literary.text: But, my dearest Jane, you cannot seriously imagine that, because Miss Bingley tells you her brother greatly admires Miss Darcy, he is in the smallest degree less sensible of _your_ merit than when he took leave of you on Tuesday; or that it will be in her power to persuade him that, instead of being in love with you, he is very much in love with her friend.” “If we thought alike of Miss Bingley,” replied Jane, “your representation of all this might make me quite easy.
paraphrases: My beloved Jane, you surely don’t really believe that because Miss Bingley claims her brother admires Miss Darcy, he is in any degree less aware of your worth than when he bade you farewell on Tuesday, or that she could convince him he is in love with her friend instead of you.” Jane replied, “If our regard for Miss Bingley were the same, your portrayal would set my mind entirely at ease.

My dearest Jane, you cannot seriously imagine that Miss Bingley’s declaration of her brother’s admiration for Miss Darcy makes him any less appreciative of your merits since Tuesday’s parting, nor that she can persuade him he’s infatuated with her friend and not you.” Jane answered, “Had we the same opinion of Miss Bingley, your description would leave me perfectly tranquil.

My darling Jane, you mustn’t truly suppose that because Miss Bingley asserts her brother holds Miss Darcy in high esteem, he values you any the less from when he took his leave on Tuesday, or that she could persuade him he’s enamored with her friend rather than you.” Jane responded, “If we thought of Miss Bingley alike, your depiction would completely reassure me.

literary.text: You will not think of quitting it in a hurry, I hope, though you have but a short lease.” “Whatever I do is done in a hurry,” replied he; “and therefore if I should resolve to quit Netherfield, I should probably be off in five minutes.
paraphrases: "I hope you won’t feel the need to depart so swiftly, despite your limited lease." He replied, "I rush through everything, and if I decided to leave Netherfield, I’d likely be gone in five minutes."

"I trust you have no plans to quit in such haste, even though your stay is brief." He said, "Everything I undertake is done hurriedly, so if I chose to abandon Netherfield, I’d be off within five minutes."

"You surely won’t choose to leave in a hurry, given your short term here." He answered, "I do all my tasks in haste, and if I resolved to give up Netherfield, I’d probably be gone in five minutes flat."

literary.text: It was some days, however, before they received any invitation thither, for while there were visitors in the house they could not be necessary; and it was not till Easter-day, almost a week after the gentlemen’s arrival, that they were honoured by such an attention, and then they were merely asked on leaving church to come there in the evening.
paraphrases: They didn’t receive an invitation for several days, since as long as there were other visitors in the house their presence wasn’t required; it wasn’t until Easter Day, nearly a week after the gentlemen’s arrival, that they were so honoured, and even then they were only asked, upon leaving church, to come there in the evening.

For some days they remained uninvited because the household was already hosting guests, and it was only on Easter Day—almost a week after the gentlemen arrived—that they were finally accorded that attention, when they were merely invited to spend the evening there as they left church.

It took several days before any invitation arrived, for while the house entertained other guests their attendance could not be necessary; only on Easter Day, almost a week after the gentlemen’s arrival, were they granted that courtesy, and then simply by being asked after church to join the evening gathering.

literary.text: She had also to anticipate how her visit would pass, the quiet tenour of their usual employments, the vexatious interruptions of Mr. Collins, and the gaieties of their intercourse with Rosings.
paraphrases: She needed to envision how her stay would unfold: the serene routine of their customary occupations, the irritating disturbances from Mr. Collins, and the cheerful moments they shared at Rosings.
She also had to forecast the course of her visit, including the calm rhythm of their everyday tasks, Mr. Collins’s annoying intrusions, and the pleasant social diversions at Rosings.

She was obliged to consider how her time there would go: the tranquil pattern of their normal activities, the bothersome interruptions by Mr. Collins, and the lively delights of their gatherings at Rosings.

literary.text: The Bennets were speedily pronounced to be the luckiest family in the world; though only a few weeks before, when Lydia had first run away, they had been generally proved to be marked out for misfortune.
paraphrases: The Bennets were swiftly declared the luckiest clan on earth, although only a few weeks prior, when Lydia first fled, they had been universally regarded as destined for ill fortune.
In no time, the Bennets were celebrated as the world’s most fortunate family, even though mere weeks before, at the moment Lydia ran off, they had been almost universally seen as doomed.
The Bennets were quickly acclaimed the luckiest household in existence; yet just weeks earlier, when Lydia initially bolted, they had been broadly judged to be marked for adversity.

literary.text: Wild rumours were circulating about her—how her mother had found her packing her bag one winter night to go to New York and say goodbye to a soldier who was going overseas.
paraphrases: Rumours ran rampant about her—how her mother had found her packing her bag on a cold winter night to head to New York and bid farewell to a soldier bound overseas.
People were abuzz with wild gossip about her—how her mother discovered her packing her bag on an icy winter night to travel to New York and say goodbye to a soldier heading abroad.
Word spread in wild whispers that her mother caught her packing her bag one frosty winter night to go to New York and see off a soldier who was being deployed overseas.

literary.text: I do not mean, however, to assert that we can be justified in devoting too much of our time to music, for there are certainly other things to be attended to.
paraphrases: I am not suggesting, however, that it is justifiable to spend too much of our time on music, since there are certainly other matters that require our attention.
However, I do not intend to claim that we have the right to devote an excessive amount of time to music, as there are undoubtedly other things to be attended to.
I do not mean to assert, though, that allocating too much time to music can be justified, for there are clearly other concerns demanding our focus.

literary.text: On being made acquainted with the present Mr. Darcy’s treatment of him, she tried to remember something of that gentleman’s reputed disposition, when quite a lad, which might agree with it; and was confident, at last, that she recollected having heard Mr. Fitzwilliam Darcy formerly spoken of as a very proud, ill-natured boy.
paraphrases: Upon learning of the way Mr Darcy now behaved towards him, she endeavoured to recall any accounts of that gentleman’s character in youth that might correspond, and at last felt certain she had heard Mr Fitzwilliam Darcy described as a very arrogant, ill-tempered child.

When informed about the current Mr Darcy’s conduct toward him, she attempted to summon to mind any recollections of that gentleman’s childhood demeanour that would fit, and finally was sure she’d heard Mr Fitzwilliam Darcy referred to as an exceedingly proud and malicious boy.

After being told how the present Mr Darcy treated him, she sought to remember something of that gentleman’s reputed nature in his younger years that might align with the behavior, and was at length convinced she had once heard Mr Fitzwilliam Darcy characterized as a haughty, ill-disposed lad.

literary.text: I saw right away he was a fine-appearing, gentlemanly young man, and when he told me he was at Oggsford I knew I could use him good.
paraphrases: I instantly perceived he was a handsome and gentlemanly young man, and upon hearing he had been at Oggsford I knew he would serve me well.
At first glance I recognized him as a well-favored, courteous youth, and when he mentioned he’d studied at Oggsford I realized how useful he could be to me.
I knew immediately he was a smartly dressed, gentlemanly young man, and once he told me of his time at Oggsford I understood I could put him to good use.

literary.text: Upon the whole, therefore, she found, what has been sometimes found before, that an event to which she had looked forward with impatient desire, did not, in taking place, bring all the satisfaction she had promised herself.
paraphrases: On the whole, she discovered, as others had occasionally discovered before, that the event she had awaited with impatient desire did not, when it took place, bring the full satisfaction she had promised herself.
Overall, she found—as had sometimes been found—that the long-anticipated occurrence, once it happened, failed to furnish all the satisfaction she had expected.
All in all, she realized, just as had been realized before, that the eagerly anticipated event did not, upon unfolding, yield the complete satisfaction she had envisioned.

literary.text: [Illustration] Elizabeth was sitting with her mother and sisters, reflecting on what she had heard, and doubting whether she was authorized to mention it, when Sir William Lucas himself appeared, sent by his daughter to announce her engagement to the family.
paraphrases: [Illustration] While Elizabeth sat with her mother and sisters, pondering what she had just heard and uncertain if she could mention it, Sir William Lucas himself arrived, sent by his daughter to announce her engagement to the family.

literary.text: When I came back they had both disappeared, so I sat down discreetly in the living-room and read a chapter of Simon Called Peter—either it was terrible stuff or the whisky distorted things, because it didn’t make any sense to me.
paraphrases: Upon returning I found them both gone, so I slipped quietly into the living-room and read a chapter of Simon Called Peter—either the writing was dreadful or the whisky was to blame, because it made no sense to me.

I came home to discover they’d both vanished, so I quietly settled into the living-room and read a chapter of Simon Called Peter—either the book was rotten or the whisky had warped my perception, since it simply baffled me.

literary.text: You will not find him more favourably spoken of by anyone.” “I cannot pretend to be sorry,” said Wickham, after a short interruption, “that he or that any man should not be estimated beyond their deserts; but with _him_ I believe it does not often happen.
paraphrases: “You won't find anyone speaking more favourably of him than you,” Wickham said after a brief pause. “I can't pretend to be sorry that he—or any man—should not be rated above his deserts; yet I believe it's rare that this happens to him.”

“No one will speak of him more favourably than you,” Wickham remarked after a short interruption. “I cannot feign regret that he, or any man, should not be esteemed beyond their deserts, but I fancy that he seldom experiences such overpraise.”

“You will hear no one speak of him more favourably than you do,” Wickham observed following a brief pause. “I can't bring myself to regret that he or any man should ever be credited beyond his deserts, and I think he rarely is.”

literary.text: Will you do me the honour of reading that letter?” and then, with a slight bow, turned again into the plantation, and was soon out of sight.
paraphrases: “Could you do me the honour of reading that letter?” With a slight bow, he turned once more toward the plantation and was quickly out of sight.

“Might I entreat you to do me the honour of reading this letter?” Then, bowing lightly, he slipped back into the plantation and was almost immediately out of sight.

literary.text: On the contrary, they were merely casual events in a crowded summer, and, until much later, they absorbed me infinitely less than my personal affairs.

literary.text: He has many friends, and he is at a time of life when friends and engagements are continually increasing.” “If he means to be but little at Netherfield, it would be better for the neighbourhood that he should give up the place entirely, for then we might possibly get a settled family there.
paraphrases: He enjoys a large circle of friends and is at an age when social ties and obligations continually multiply; if he means to spend only a short time at Netherfield, it would be better for the neighbourhood if he gave up the estate entirely, since then we might have a settled family there.

He has countless acquaintances and finds himself at a stage of life where invitations and friendships steadily increase; should he only rarely occupy Netherfield, it would benefit the neighbourhood for him to relinquish the property altogether so that we might secure a permanent household there.

With a wide network of friends and being at a point in life when engagements and relationships keep growing, if he intends to be scarcely at Netherfield, it would be preferable for the neighbourhood that he abandon the place completely, thereby offering us the chance to welcome a settled family.

literary.text: Their visit did not continue long after the question and answer above mentioned; and while Mr. Darcy was attending them to their carriage, Miss Bingley was venting her feelings in criticisms on Elizabeth’s person, behaviour, and dress.
paraphrases: Their visit didn't last long after the question and answer mentioned above, and while Mr. Darcy escorted them to their carriage, Miss Bingley vented her feelings by criticizing Elizabeth’s appearance, behaviour, and attire.

literary.text: The dinner, too, in its turn, was highly admired; and he begged to know to which of his fair cousins the excellence of its cookery was owing.
paraphrases: The meal likewise received great acclaim, and he eagerly inquired to which of his lovely cousins he owed the credit for its superior preparation.

The feast, accordingly, was met with enthusiastic admiration, prompting him to ask which of his fair cousins was responsible for its exceptional cuisine.

literary.text: “You always have a green light that burns all night at the end of your dock.” Daisy put her arm through his abruptly, but he seemed absorbed in what he had just said.
paraphrases: “There’s always a green light glowing all night at the tip of your dock,” Daisy said as she slipped her arm through his suddenly, but he remained wholly absorbed in his own remark.
“A green lamp at the end of your dock burns through the night,” Daisy interjected, threading her arm into his without warning, yet he appeared fixated on his own words.
“You keep a green beacon shining all night at your dock’s end,” Daisy hooked her arm around his abruptly, but he seemed lost in thought over what he had just said.

literary.text: But Mr. Bennet was not of a disposition to seek comfort for the disappointment which his own imprudence had brought on in any of those pleasures which too often console the unfortunate for their folly or their vice.
paraphrases: However, Mr. Bennet was not inclined to seek solace in any of the pleasures that often soothe the unfortunate for their folly or vice, despite the disappointment his own imprudence had caused.

Mr. Bennet, however, had no disposition to find consolation in the very diversions that frequently comfort the unfortunate for their mistakes or vices, even though his own recklessness had brought him disappointment.

literary.text: And now do, when you get to town, find them out, wherever they may be; and if they are not married already, _make_ them marry.

literary.text: “Why’s that?” “Daisy’s leaving you.” “Nonsense.” “I am, though,” she said with a visible effort.
paraphrases: “How come?” “Daisy’s leaving you.” “That’s ridiculous.” “I really am,” she said, forcing herself to speak.
“What makes you think so?” “Daisy’s walking away from you.” “You must be joking.” “I’m serious,” she said, struggling to get the words out.
“Why do you say that?” “Daisy’s breaking up with you.” “Preposterous.” “Yet here I am,” she said with a visible effort.

literary.text: It was Gatsby’s father, a solemn old man, very helpless and dismayed, bundled up in a long cheap ulster against the warm September day.
paraphrases: Gatsby’s father, a solemn elderly man, entirely helpless and dismayed, wrapped in a long, cheap ulster despite the warm September day.

literary.text: The former was divided between admiration of the brilliancy which exercise had given to her complexion and doubt as to the occasion’s justifying her coming so far alone.
paraphrases: She was at once admiring the radiance exercise had bestowed upon her complexion and doubting whether the occasion justified her making such a long journey alone.

She felt divided between appreciation for the brightness exercise had given her complexion and uncertainty about whether the occasion justified her venturing so far alone.

literary.text: “Come along with me for a minute,” I said; “I’ve got to say hello to someone.” When he saw us Tom jumped up and took half a dozen steps in our direction.
paraphrases: “Come with me for a moment,” I said; “I need to say hello to someone.” The moment he noticed us, Tom sprang up and covered half a dozen paces in our direction.

“Stay by my side for a moment,” I said; “There’s someone I want to say hello to.” Tom saw us, jumped up, and closed in on us in about half a dozen steps.

literary.text: They were of course all intending to be surprised: but their astonishment was beyond their expectation; and on the part of Mrs. Bennet and Kitty, though she was perfectly unknown to them, even inferior to what Elizabeth felt.
paraphrases: They had all, of course, meant to look surprised, yet their wonder exceeded their expectations; and in the case of Mrs. Bennet and Kitty—between whom she was a total stranger—it was even less than what Elizabeth felt.

Naturally they all designed to feign surprise; however, their astonishment surpassed anything they'd anticipated, and for Mrs. Bennet and Kitty, to whom she was wholly unknown, it remained inferior to Elizabeth’s.

They intended, as might be expected, to appear astonished; yet their amazement surpassed their imaginings, and for Mrs. Bennet and Kitty—among whom she was perfectly unknown—it was even inferior to what Elizabeth experienced.

literary.text: “It is unlucky,” said she, after a short pause, “that you should not be able to see your friends before they leave the country.

literary.text: In future, I hope we shall be always of one mind.” She held out her hand: he kissed it with affectionate gallantry, though he hardly knew how to look, and they entered the house.
paraphrases: “Looking forward, I trust we shall ever be of one mind.” She extended her hand; he greeted it with a fond, chivalrous kiss, though he hardly knew where to cast his eyes, and they entered the house.

literary.text: It appears to me so very unlikely that any young man should form such a design against a girl who is by no means unprotected or friendless, and who was actually staying in his Colonel’s family, that I am strongly inclined to hope the best.
paraphrases: I consider it highly improbable that a young man would conceive such intentions toward a girl who is neither unprotected nor friendless and who is in fact residing with his Colonel’s family; therefore, I am inclined to remain optimistic.

literary.text: _That_ is my idea of good breeding; and those persons who fancy themselves very important and never open their mouths quite mistake the matter.” “Did Charlotte dine with you?” “No, she would go home.
paraphrases: “That, to my mind, is true breeding; those who fancy themselves too important to speak are utterly mistaken.” “Did Charlotte dine with you?” “No, she would rather go home.”

“In my view, that exemplifies proper breeding; individuals who imagine themselves too dignified to speak are quite mistaken.” “Did Charlotte dine with you?” “No, she would go home.”

literary.text: On entering the drawing-room, she found the whole party at loo, and was immediately invited to join them; but suspecting them to be playing high, she declined it, and making her sister the excuse, said she would amuse herself, for the short time she could stay below, with a book.
