literary.text: But really, and upon my honour, I will try to do what I think to be wisest; and now I hope you are satisfied.” Her aunt assured her that she was; and Elizabeth, having thanked her for the kindness of her hints, they parted,--a wonderful instance of advice being given on such a point without being resented.
paraphrases: “Upon my honour, I really will endeavour to follow what I deem wisest, and I trust you are now satisfied,” her aunt replied that she was; and Elizabeth, thanking her for her considerate hints, they parted—a remarkable instance of advice given without offence.

“But truly, on my word, I shall strive to do what seems wisest to me, and I hope it meets with your approval,” her aunt assured her that it did; and after Elizabeth expressed her gratitude for the gracious guidance, they took their leave—a striking example of counsel offered without resentment.

“Honestly, upon my honour, I will attempt to conduct myself in the wisest manner I know, and I hope you find it acceptable,” her aunt said she did; and Elizabeth, thanking her for her kind suggestions, they parted—a wonderful case of advice bestowed without being taken amiss.

literary.text: It settled the matter; and they pursued the accustomed circuit; which brought them again, after some time, in a descent among hanging woods, to the edge of the water, and one of its narrowest parts.
paraphrases: This resolved the matter, and they resumed their familiar circuit, which after a while led them down through hanging woods to the water’s edge at one of its narrowest points.
With the question settled, they followed their accustomed route again, and eventually descended among overhanging trees to reach the shore where the water was at its slimmest.
Having settled the issue, they pursued their usual course, which brought them after some time through pendent woods to the brink of the water at one of its most constrained stretches.

literary.text: But before they heard again from Mr. Gardiner, a letter arrived for their father, from a different quarter, from Mr. Collins; which, as Jane had received directions to open all that came for him in his absence, she accordingly read; and Elizabeth, who knew what curiosities his letters always were, looked over her, and read it likewise.
paraphrases: However, before they heard again from Mr. Gardiner, their father received a letter from another source, Mr. Collins; Jane, having been instructed to open all mail addressed to him during his absence, complied and read it, and Elizabeth, aware of the peculiar interest of his missives, peered over her sister’s shoulder and read it too.

Yet prior to receiving any further news from Mr. Gardiner, a dispatch arrived for their father from Mr. Collins, which Jane, charged with opening all correspondence addressed to him while he was away, dutifully opened; and Elizabeth, knowing the curious contents of his letters, glanced over her and read it as well.

Before any more word came from Mr. Gardiner, their father got a letter from Mr. Collins by a different route, and Jane, who had orders to open all such letters in his absence, immediately read it, while Elizabeth, expecting some oddities in his writing, looked on and read it too.

literary.text: And on Mondays eight servants, including an extra gardener, toiled all day with mops and scrubbing-brushes and hammers and garden-shears, repairing the ravages of the night before.
paraphrases: Each Monday, eight servants—including an extra gardener—toiled all day with mops, scrubbing brushes, hammers, and garden shears to repair the damage from the night before.

On Mondays, a group of eight servants, including an additional gardener, spent the entire day working with mops and scrubbing brushes, hammers and garden shears, restoring what the previous night had ravaged.
Every Monday, eight servants—among them an extra gardener—labored throughout the day with mops, scrubbing brushes, hammers, and garden shears, mending the destruction left overnight.

literary.text: Wickham” by each of them; and in the meantime she went after dinner to show her ring and boast of being married to Mrs. Hill and the two housemaids.
paraphrases: Everyone repeated “Wickham,” and meanwhile she went after dinner to show her ring and boast of being married to Mrs. Hill and the two housemaids.
Each of them said “Wickham,” and in the interim she, post-dinner, flaunted her ring and proudly claimed she was wed to Mrs. Hill and the two maids.
All of them uttered “Wickham,” while she, following dinner, displayed her ring and bragged that she was married to Mrs. Hill and the two housemaids.

literary.text: “I’ll give it to him when he gets back.” “But I know he’s there.” She took a step toward me and began to slide her hands indignantly up and down her hips.
paraphrases: “I’ll hand it to him once he’s back.” “But I know he’s here.” She stepped toward me, sliding her hands indignantly up and down her hips.
“I’ll give it to him as soon as he returns.” “But I can see he’s right here.” She moved closer to me, her hands gliding angrily along her hips.
“Once he gets back, I’ll pass it to him.” “But he’s clearly here.” She advanced on me, sliding her hands irritably up and down her hips.
He performed exceptionally well on the battlefield during the war.
He achieved remarkable success throughout the war.
He excelled brilliantly in all his wartime engagements.

literary.text: “I have spent four days in the same house with him, and I think him very disagreeable.” “I have no right to give _my_ opinion,” said Wickham, “as to his being agreeable or otherwise.
paraphrases: “I have been in the same house with him for four days, and I find him exceedingly disagreeable.” “I have no right to offer _my_ view,” said Wickham, “on whether he is agreeable or not.”
“After four days under the same roof, I must say he strikes me as very disagreeable.” “I’m not really entitled to voice _my_ opinion,” said Wickham, “on his being pleasant or otherwise.”
“Having shared a house with him for four days, I find him quite disagreeable.” “I have no right to give _my_ judgment,” said Wickham, “on how agreeable he may be.”

literary.text: Choose properly, choose a gentlewoman for _my_ sake, and for your _own_; let her be an active, useful sort of person, not brought up high, but able to make a small income go a good way.
paraphrases: Choose wisely, selecting a gentlewoman both for my benefit and yours, someone energetic and practical, not reared in affluence, but able to stretch a modest income.
Make a careful choice—seek a gentlewoman for our mutual sake who is diligent and resourceful, not accustomed to luxury, yet adept at making limited means suffice.
Be cautious in your selection: pick a gentlewoman for my sake and your own who is active and supportive, unspoiled by high upbringing, but skilled at making a small income go far.

literary.text: They were then, with no other delay than his pointing out the neatness of the entrance, taken into the house; and as soon as they were in the parlour, he welcomed them a second time, with ostentatious formality, to his humble abode, and punctually repeated all his wife’s offers of refreshment.
paraphrases: They were then admitted into the house—with only his remark on the entrance’s tidiness delaying them—and as soon as they were in the parlour he welcomed them again with ostentatious ceremony to his humble abode, promptly echoing every offer of refreshment his wife had made.

Having paused solely to admire the neatness of the entrance, they were led inside; once in the parlour he formally greeted them a second time to his modest home and dutifully repeated all his wife’s offers of refreshments.

Except for his compliment on the entrance’s cleanliness, their entry was uninterrupted, and as soon as they reached the parlour he received them anew with grandiose politeness to his unassuming dwelling, meticulously restating every invitation to refreshment from his wife.

literary.text: Miss Lydia is going to be married; and you shall all have a bowl of punch to make merry at her wedding.” Mrs. Hill began instantly to express her joy.
paraphrases: “Miss Lydia is to be married, and each of you will have a bowl of punch to enjoy her wedding festivities.” Mrs. Hill immediately expressed her delight.
“Miss Lydia will soon be married; and everyone here shall be served a bowl of punch to partake in the merriment at her wedding.” Mrs. Hill wasted no time in showing her joy.
“Miss Lydia is getting married, and you shall all receive a bowl of punch to celebrate her nuptials.” Mrs. Hill at once began to demonstrate her happiness.

literary.text: “Daisy invited him; she knew him before we were married—God knows where!” We were all irritable now with the fading ale, and aware of it we drove for a while in silence.
paraphrases: "Daisy had asked him along; she’d known him long before we were married—God only knows from where! The ale had worn off, leaving us all irritable, and realizing it, we drove on in silence for a bit."

"Daisy invited him along, claiming she knew him from before our wedding—where on earth, nobody knows! As the ale’s effects faded, we all grew edgy, and aware of that, we kept driving in silence for a while."
"Daisy asked him to join us; she’d known him before our marriage—God knows from where! With the ale running out, we felt testy, and once we noticed, we continued to drive in silence for some time."

literary.text: No one who has ever seen you together can doubt his affection; Miss Bingley, I am sure, cannot: she is not such a simpleton.
paraphrases: Anyone who has witnessed you together cannot question his affection; I am certain Miss Bingley recognizes it too—she is no simpleton.
All who have seen you side by side are convinced of his devotion; I’m sure Miss Bingley understands as well, for she’s no fool.
No one who has observed the two of you in each other’s company can doubt his feelings; Miss Bingley, I’m sure, is too perceptive to be unaware.

literary.text: He wisely resolved to be particularly careful that no sign of admiration should _now_ escape him--nothing that could elevate her with the hope of influencing his felicity; sensible that, if such an idea had been suggested, his behaviour during the last day must have material weight in confirming or crushing it.
paraphrases: He prudently resolved to be especially careful that no hint of admiration should now escape him—nothing that might raise her hopes of influencing his happiness; aware that, if such a notion had been suggested, his conduct in the past day would carry significant weight in confirming or dispelling it.

Judiciously he determined to guard against any sign of admiration now—nothing capable of elevating her expectations of affecting his felicity; sensible that, if such an idea had taken root, his behaviour during the last day would have a material impact in affirming or crushing it.

He wisely pledged to be particularly vigilant so that no expression of admiration slipped out now—nothing to inflate her hopes of swaying his well-being; conscious that, were such a thought implied, his actions over the previous day would be pivotal in proving or refuting it.

literary.text: I was on my way to get roaring drunk from sheer embarrassment when Jordan Baker came out of the house and stood at the head of the marble steps, leaning a little backward and looking with contemptuous interest down into the garden.
paraphrases: Just as I headed off to drown my humiliation in drink, Jordan Baker emerged from the house and paused at the top of the marble steps, leaning slightly back as she surveyed the garden with disdainful curiosity.

I was about to seek oblivion through furious drinking to soothe my mortification when Jordan Baker appeared at the doorway, perching at the summit of the marble stairs, reclining marginally and gazing upon the garden with a scornful air.

Embarrassment drove me toward rampant intoxication just as Jordan Baker stepped outside, positioning herself atop the marble staircase, leaning back a touch and regarding the garden below with disdainful intrigue.

literary.text: As she went upstairs to get ready, Mrs. Bennet followed her, saying,-- “I am quite sorry, Lizzy, that you should be forced to have that disagreeable man all to yourself; but I hope you will not mind it.
paraphrases: As she climbed the stairs to prepare, Mrs. Bennet followed close behind, saying, "I’m truly sorry, Lizzy, that you must be stuck alone with that disagreeable man; but I trust you won’t mind."

While she went upstairs to dress, Mrs. Bennet trailed after her, commenting, "I feel quite sorry, Lizzy, that you are compelled to have that unpleasant fellow all to yourself; however, I hope it won’t inconvenience you."
She ascended the stairs to get ready, Mrs. Bennet at her heels, lamenting, "I regret, Lizzy, that you are obliged to spend time alone with that disagreeable man, yet I hope it will not trouble you."

literary.text: I am very sensible of the honour of your proposals, but it is impossible for me to do otherwise than decline them.” “I am not now to learn,” replied Mr. Collins, with a formal wave of the hand, “that it is usual with young ladies to reject the addresses of the man whom they secretly mean to accept, when he first applies for their favour; and that sometimes the refusal is repeated a second or even a third time.
paraphrases: “I deeply appreciate the honour of your proposal, but I must inevitably decline,” she replied. “I well know,” Mr. Collins answered with a formal wave, “that young ladies often first refuse the man they secretly intend to accept, sometimes even a second or third time.”

“I am truly grateful for the courtesy of your offer, yet I cannot do otherwise than refuse,” she said. “I am not unaware,” Mr. Collins responded with a ceremonious gesture, “that it is customary for ladies to reject the suitor they really mean to accept on the first, second, or even third proposal.”

“I am sincerely honoured by your proposal, but I have no choice but to decline,” she answered. “I have learned,” Mr. Collins replied with a formal wave of the hand, “that it is usual for young ladies to refuse the addresses of the man they secretly intend to accept, sometimes not just once but twice or thrice.”

literary.text: I have been meditating on the very great pleasure which a pair of fine eyes in the face of a pretty woman can bestow.” Miss Bingley immediately fixed her eyes on his face, and desired he would tell her what lady had the credit of inspiring such reflections.
paraphrases: I’ve been pondering the immense pleasure that the fine eyes of a pretty woman can bestow, and Miss Bingley immediately fixed her gaze on his face, urging him to name the lady who had inspired such reflections.

He admitted he had been reflecting on the profound delight afforded by a charming woman’s beautiful eyes, whereupon Miss Bingley at once turned her eyes toward him and desired to know which lady deserved credit for those thoughts.

He confessed he’d been meditating on the great enjoyment a pretty woman’s lovely eyes could grant, prompting Miss Bingley to lock her gaze on his face and insist he reveal which lady had prompted such sentiments.

literary.text: “Is Miss Darcy much grown since the spring?” said Miss Bingley: “will she be as tall as I am?” “I think she will.
paraphrases: “Has Miss Darcy grown much since spring?” asked Miss Bingley. “Will she be as tall as I am?” “I think she will.”
“Do you think Miss Darcy has grown considerably since spring?” inquired Miss Bingley. “Might she match my height?” “I believe she will.”
“Is Miss Darcy taller now than she was in spring?” Miss Bingley asked. “Could she be as tall as me?” “I think she will.”

literary.text: I was so vexed to see him stand up with her; but, however, he did not admire her at all; indeed, nobody can, you know; and he seemed quite struck with Jane as she was going down the dance.
paraphrases: I was greatly displeased to observe him standing up with her; nevertheless, he had no admiration for her in the least; indeed, nobody possibly could; and he seemed utterly captivated by Jane as she went down the dance.

My vexation at seeing him partner with her was profound; however, he found nothing at all to admire in her; truly, it would be impossible; and he appeared quite entranced by Jane as she descended the dance.
I felt such annoyance when he rose with her; yet he admired her not one bit; no one ever could, for that matter; and he looked completely taken with Jane while she was going down the dance.

literary.text: She ran out to speak to him and he wouldn’t stop.” Michaelis had seen this too, but it hadn’t occurred to him that there was any special significance in it.
paraphrases: She rushed outside to speak with him, and he refused to pause; Michaelis had seen this too, but he hadn’t thought it held any special meaning.
She darted out to address him, yet he simply wouldn’t stop. Michaelis had witnessed it as well, but he didn’t perceive it as particularly significant.
She hurried out to talk to him, and he wouldn’t cease; Michaelis noticed it too, though he hadn’t attributed any special importance to it.

literary.text: Miss Darcy, on her brother’s entrance, exerted herself much more to talk; and Elizabeth saw that he was anxious for his sister and herself to get acquainted, and forwarded, as much as possible, every attempt at conversation on either side.
paraphrases: When her brother entered, Miss Darcy strove much harder to join the conversation, and Elizabeth noticed that he was eager for the two sisters to become acquainted, promoting every conversational effort from either side.

Upon Colonel Darcy’s arrival, his sister exerted herself considerably more in talking, and Elizabeth perceived his wish for them to form a closeness, advancing each attempt at dialogue by either party whenever he could.

At the moment her brother appeared, Miss Darcy increased her efforts in conversation, and Elizabeth observed his anxiety for his sister and herself to get acquainted, supporting every exchange of words on both sides.

literary.text: He had changed it at the age of seventeen and at the specific moment that witnessed the beginning of his career—when he saw Dan Cody’s yacht drop anchor over the most insidious flat on Lake Superior.
paraphrases: At seventeen, he altered it precisely at the instant his career began—when Dan Cody’s yacht dropped anchor above the most treacherous shoal on Lake Superior.
It was at seventeen that he modified it exactly at the moment that marked the start of his professional life—when he watched Dan Cody’s yacht lower its anchor over Lake Superior’s most perilous flat.
He changed it at seventeen, right at the pivotal moment his career launched—when Dan Cody’s yacht cast anchor atop the most dangerous flat in Lake Superior.

literary.text: The country is a vast deal pleasanter, is not it, Mr. Bingley?” “When I am in the country,” he replied, “I never wish to leave it; and when I am in town, it is pretty much the same.
paraphrases: "The countryside is far more delightful, don’t you agree, Mr. Bingley?” “When I’m in the country,” he answered, “I never care to depart; and in town, it’s much the same.”
“Isn’t the country infinitely more pleasant, Mr. Bingley?” “Whenever I’m in the country,” he replied, “I have no desire to leave; and in town, I feel just as satisfied.”
“The country is so much more agreeable, wouldn’t you say, Mr. Bingley?” “I never wish to quit when I’m there,” he said, “and when I’m in town, I feel equally content.”

literary.text: When she did come, it was very evident that she had no pleasure in it; she made a slight, formal apology for not calling before, said not a word of wishing to see me again, and was, in every respect, so altered a creature, that when she went away I was perfectly resolved to continue the acquaintance no longer.
paraphrases: When she finally appeared, it was abundantly clear she derived no pleasure from the visit; she offered a brief, formal apology for not notifying me earlier, made no mention of wanting to see me again, and, in every respect, was so utterly changed that after her departure I resolved never to renew our acquaintance.

When she did show up, it was obvious she enjoyed it not in the least; she delivered a slight, courteous apology for not calling ahead, refrained entirely from expressing any desire to meet again, and proved such an altered person that once she left I was determined to end our connection.

When she arrived at last, it became perfectly evident that she took no delight in it; she made a terse, polite apology for her failure to call beforehand, uttered not a word about wanting to see me again, and was, in every aspect, so transformed that upon her departure I was resolved to discontinue the acquaintance.

literary.text: Mrs. Bennet was privileged to whisper it to Mrs. Philips, and she ventured, without any permission, to do the same by all her neighbours in Meryton.
paraphrases: Mrs. Bennet had the pleasure of whispering it to Mrs. Philips, and she dared, without seeking permission, to do the same with all her neighbours in Meryton.
Mrs. Bennet enjoyed the honor of confiding it to Mrs. Philips, and, without any authorisation, she also relayed it to every neighbour in Meryton.
Mrs. Bennet was fortunate enough to impart it to Mrs. Philips, and she proceeded, without having obtained permission, to share it with all her neighbours in Meryton.

literary.text: The situation of your mother’s family, though objectionable, was nothing in comparison of that total want of propriety so frequently, so almost uniformly betrayed by herself, by your three younger sisters, and occasionally even by your father:--pardon me,--it pains me to offend you.
paraphrases: Although your mother’s family’s conduct was objectionable, it was negligible compared to the pervasive lack of decorum consistently displayed by her, by your three younger sisters, and even at times by your father—pardon me—it grieves me to cause offence.

Your maternal relatives’ behavior, while distasteful, paled beside the blatant impropriety so regularly, so almost invariably exhibited by your mother, by your three younger sisters, and occasionally by your father—excuse me—it pains me to give offence.

Even though the state of your mother’s kin was offensive, it amounted to little next to the complete absence of propriety so often, so nearly without exception, shown by her, your three younger sisters, and sometimes by your father—please forgive me—I mean no offence.

literary.text: The gentleman experienced some change of feeling; he drew back his chair, took a newspaper from the table, and, glancing over it, said, in a colder voice,-- “Are you pleased with Kent?” A short dialogue on the subject of the country ensued, on either side calm and concise--and soon put an end to by the entrance of Charlotte and her sister, just returned from their walk.
paraphrases: Noticing a shift in his disposition, the gentleman pushed his chair away, lifted a newspaper from the table, and after a cursory glance, asked in a more reserved tone, “Are you satisfied with Kent?” A brief, composed conversation about the county ensued, which was soon interrupted by the appearance of Charlotte and her sister, freshly returned from their walk.

His feelings having changed, he drew his chair back, picked up a newspaper from the table, and, casting a swift look at it, spoke in a colder voice: “Are you pleased with Kent?” A short, calm, and concise discussion on the region followed, only to be cut short when Charlotte and her sister reentered after their walk.

Experiencing a sudden chill in his mood, the gentleman slid his chair back, grabbed a newspaper off the table and, skimming the pages, uttered in a cooler tone, “Are you content with Kent?” An equally calm and succinct dialogue about the county followed, but was promptly ended by Charlotte and her sister’s return from their stroll.

literary.text: Why did not you seek legal redress?” “There was just such an informality in the terms of the bequest as to give me no hope from law.
paraphrases: “Why did you not seek legal remedy?” “The bequest’s terms were so informal that I had no hope of gaining anything through the law.”
“Why didn’t you pursue relief in court?” “The stipulations of the bequest were too informal for me to expect any legal support.”
“Why did you not turn to the courts for redress?” “The language of the bequest was so loosely framed that I couldn’t hope for any judicial assistance.”

literary.text: She was busily searching through the neighbourhood for a proper situation for her daughter; and, without knowing or considering what their income might be, rejected many as deficient in size and importance.
paraphrases: She busied herself scouring the neighborhood for an appropriate placement for her daughter, and, without inquiring into or weighing their earnings, dismissed many as lacking in status and prestige.

She actively combed the surroundings seeking a fitting appointment for her daughter; and, unaware of or indifferent to their financial means, turned down numerous prospects as too modest and unremarkable.

She was occupied with canvassing the neighborhood to find a suitable post for her daughter, and, having neither asked about nor considered their salaries, deemed many unworthy due to their limited standing and influence.

literary.text: She felt that Jane’s feelings, though fervent, were little displayed, and that there was a constant complacency in her air and manner, not often united with great sensibility.
paraphrases: She believed that although Jane's sentiments ran deep, she showed them little, and that her demeanor maintained a constant self-satisfaction, rarely joined by genuine sensitivity.
In her view, Jane's fervent emotions were seldom on display, and her air and manner exuded a steady complacency, scarcely blended with true sensibility.
She perceived that Jane’s feelings, though intense, remained largely hidden, and that a persistent smugness in her bearing was seldom accompanied by profound sensibility.

literary.text: You blamed me for coming?” “No, indeed, I felt nothing but surprise.” “Your surprise could not be greater than _mine_ in being noticed by you.
paraphrases: “Did you reproach me for turning up?” “Absolutely not; I was nothing but astonished.” “Yet your astonishment couldn’t surpass mine at being observed by you.”
“You thought I was at fault for arriving?” “On the contrary, I was purely taken by surprise.” “Still, my surprise at catching your eye was greater than yours at seeing me.”
“Were you critical of my presence?” “Not in the slightest; I was simply amazed.” “However, your amazement couldn’t top mine when you noticed me.”

literary.text: There was now employment for the whole party; for though they could not all talk, they could all eat; and the beautiful pyramids of grapes, nectarines, and peaches, soon collected them round the table.
paraphrases: The entire party was now occupied; though they could not all speak, they could all partake in the feast; and the beautiful pyramids of grapes, nectarines, and peaches soon drew them round the table.

Everyone at last had something to do; because even if conversation eluded some, eating was open to all; and before long the splendid pyramids of grapes, nectarines, and peaches gathered them round the table.

At this point the whole company found employment; for while not every guest could talk, every guest could eat; and the gorgeous pyramids of grapes, nectarines, and peaches quickly collected them round the table.

literary.text: It had given him a disgust to his business and to his residence in a small market town; and, quitting them both, he had removed with his family to a house about a mile from Meryton, denominated from that period Lucas Lodge; where he could think with pleasure of his own importance, and, unshackled by business, occupy himself solely in being civil to all the world.
paraphrases: He had grown disgusted with his trade and with living in a small market town; so, abandoning both, he moved his family to a house about a mile from Meryton, which from then on was called Lucas Lodge, where, freed from business cares, he could delight in his own importance and devote himself entirely to civility toward everyone.

His business and his residence in the modest market town had come to disgust him; thus he left them and settled with his family at a house about a mile from Meryton, henceforth named Lucas Lodge, where, liberated from commercial burdens, he could take pleasure in his own self-importance and attend exclusively to being polite to all.

Repelled by his trade and by life in a small market town, he forsook both and relocated with his family to a dwelling about a mile from Meryton, which he named Lucas Lodge, and there, unencumbered by business, he could joyfully contemplate his own significance and devote himself solely to courteousness toward everyone.

literary.text: I will go directly to Mr. Bennet, and we shall very soon settle it with her, I am sure.” She would not give him time to reply, but hurrying instantly to her husband, called out, as she entered the library,-- “Oh, Mr. Bennet, you are wanted immediately; we are all in an uproar.
paraphrases: Declaring she would go straight to Mr. Bennet and convinced they would resolve it with her at once, she cut him off and hurried to her husband, bursting into the library to exclaim, “Oh, Mr. Bennet, you’re needed immediately; we’re all in an uproar!”

Without giving him a moment to reply, she insisted she would visit Mr. Bennet directly and settle things with her instantly, then rushed into the library calling, “Oh, Mr. Bennet, come here at once; we’re all in a state of commotion!”

She declared she would go immediately to Mr. Bennet and resolve the matter with her without waiting for his answer, hastened into the library, and cried, “Oh, Mr. Bennet, you’re wanted at once; we’re all in an uproar!”

literary.text: The sister, Catherine, was a slender, worldly girl of about thirty, with a solid, sticky bob of red hair, and a complexion powdered milky white.
paraphrases: Catherine, the sister, was a slender, worldly woman of about thirty, with a firm, sticky bob of red hair and a powdered milky-white complexion.
The sister Catherine was a lean and worldly thirty-year-old, her red hair cut into a solid, tacky bob and her skin dusted milky white.
Sister Catherine, around thirty, was slim and worldly, sporting a stiff, adhesive red bob and a face powdered milky white.

literary.text: I had not been long in Hertfordshire before I saw, in common with others, that Bingley preferred your elder sister to any other young woman in the country.
paraphrases: Not long after my arrival in Hertfordshire I observed, as did everyone else, that Bingley favored your elder sister above all other young ladies in the country.
It was not long since I came to Hertfordshire before I noticed, like others, that Bingley esteemed your elder sister more highly than any other young woman in the country.
Shortly after arriving in Hertfordshire I perceived, as everyone else had, that Bingley held your elder sister in greater regard than any comparable young woman in the land.

literary.text: To work in his garden was one of his most respectable pleasures; and Elizabeth admired the command of countenance with which Charlotte talked of the healthfulness of the exercise, and owned she encouraged it as much as possible.
paraphrases: One of his most honorable pastimes was tending his garden, and Elizabeth admired the composed way in which Charlotte spoke of its health benefits and confessed she promoted it whenever she could.

Tending his garden stood among his most respectable enjoyments; Elizabeth was struck by how composedly Charlotte extolled the exercise’s health advantages and admitted she encouraged it at every opportunity.

Working in the garden ranked high among his most esteemed pleasures, and Elizabeth admired Charlotte’s calm demeanor when praising the exercise’s healthfulness, acknowledging that she endorsed it whenever possible.

literary.text: With his notions of dignity, he would probably feel that the arguments, which to Elizabeth had appeared weak and ridiculous, contained much good sense and solid reasoning.
paraphrases: Given his sense of dignity, he would likely see that the arguments Elizabeth had deemed weak and ridiculous actually possessed considerable good sense and sound reasoning.
Because of his notions of dignity, he would probably view the arguments—so feeble and absurd to Elizabeth—as full of solid reasoning and sensible insight.
With his view of dignity, he would most likely believe that the arguments Elizabeth found weak and laughable were in fact rich in good sense and strong logic.

literary.text: They used to run a small hotel.” “I see.” He was calling up at Daisy’s request—would I come to lunch at her house tomorrow?
paraphrases: They once ran a small hotel. “I understand,” he said as he called at Daisy’s request to ask if I could come to lunch at her house tomorrow.
They formerly managed a modest hotel. “Got it.” He rang Daisy up at her behest—would I join her for lunch at her place the next day?
They had operated a little inn. “Right.” He was calling on Daisy’s instruction to invite me to lunch at her home tomorrow.

literary.text: “It’s stopped raining.” “Has it?” When he realized what I was talking about, that there were twinkle-bells of sunshine in the room, he smiled like a weather man, like an ecstatic patron of recurrent light, and repeated the news to Daisy.
paraphrases: “The rain has let up.” “Has it?” When he caught my meaning—those glinting sparkles of sunshine filling the room—he flashed a weather man’s smile, like a rapt connoisseur of returning light, and relayed the news to Daisy.

“It’s stopped pouring.” “Really?” As soon as he understood I meant the room was bright with twinkling sunbeams, he beamed like an ecstatic meteorologist, a devoted admirer of the light’s comeback, then repeated the discovery to Daisy.

“The downpour’s over.” “Is that so?” Once he realized I was pointing to the glittering bells of sunshine in the room, he grinned like a weather forecaster, like an enraptured patron of reborn light, and passed the update on to Daisy.

literary.text: I hope your plans in favour of the ----shire will not be affected by his being in the neighbourhood.” “Oh no--it is not for _me_ to be driven away by Mr. Darcy.
paraphrases: “I trust your plans for the ----shire won’t be troubled by his presence in the neighbourhood.” “Heavens, no—it’s not for Mr. Darcy to drive me off.”
“I hope your designs concerning the ----shire remain untouched by his vicinity.” “Certainly not—I won’t let Mr. Darcy force me away.”
“I pray that your arrangements for the ----shire aren’t upset by his being about.” “By no means—it’s not Mr. Darcy who will make me yield my ground.”

literary.text: “But surely,” said she, “I may enter his county with impunity, and rob it of a few petrified spars, without his perceiving me.” The period of expectation was now doubled.
paraphrases: “But surely,” she replied, “I can enter his county unpunished and steal a few petrified spars without him detecting me.” The period of expectation was now doubled.
“Yet I may,” she observed, “venture into his county with impunity and purloin some petrified spars without his noticing.” The period of expectation was now doubled.
“However,” she said, “I’m at liberty to roam his county unharmed and filch a few petrified spars without his awareness.” The period of expectation was now doubled.

literary.text: But in all, and in almost every line of each, there was a want of that cheerfulness which had been used to characterize her style, and which, proceeding from the serenity of a mind at ease with itself, and kindly disposed towards everyone, had been scarcely ever clouded.
paraphrases: Yet throughout nearly every passage, the cheerfulness that once defined her writing was conspicuously absent—a cheerfulness born of a peaceful, self-assured mind and a warm disposition towards all, which had rarely faltered.

However, in virtually every segment, one noticed the absence of the buoyancy that had distinguished her prose, a buoyancy that stemmed from a tranquil, contented spirit and benevolent regard for others, seldom overshadowed.

But in almost all parts, the liveliness that once marked her style was missing, a liveliness arising from a calm, self-contented mind and a kindly attitude toward everyone, and one that had almost never dimmed.

literary.text: [Illustration] With no greater events than these in the Longbourn family, and otherwise diversified by little beyond the walks to Meryton, sometimes dirty and sometimes cold, did January and February pass away.
paraphrases: In the Longbourn household, no events were more significant than these, and the only variation came from their walks to Meryton, sometimes muddy, sometimes cold, as January and February slipped away.

January and February passed in the Longbourn family with nothing grander occurring than these few events, and little to break the monotony other than the occasionally dirty, occasionally chilly walks to Meryton.
With no occurrence in the Longbourn family exceeding these, and scarce variation beyond the sometimes filthy, sometimes frigid strolls to Meryton, January and February quietly elapsed.

literary.text: You dare not, you cannot deny that you have been the principal, if not the only means of dividing them from each other, of exposing one to the censure of the world for caprice and instability, the other to its derision for disappointed hopes, and involving them both in misery of the acutest kind.” She paused, and saw with no slight indignation that he was listening with an air which proved him wholly unmoved by any feeling of remorse.
paraphrases: “You have the audacity to deny that you were the chief, if not the sole, cause of their separation, that you subjected one to the world’s reproach for whim and instability and the other to its scorn for thwarted expectations, plunging them both into the sharpest anguish.” She paused and observed, with more than slight indignation, that he listened with an expression betraying not a trace of remorse.

“It is impossible for you to deny that you played the leading role—perhaps the only one—in tearing them apart, in exposing one to public condemnation for frivolity and fickleness, and the other to ridicule for dashed hopes, and in consigning them both to the most acute suffering.” She stopped and, with palpable indignation, noticed that his demeanor showed no sign of regret.

“You cannot possibly refuse that you were the main, if not the exclusive, instrument of their estrangement, that you brought one under the world’s criticism for capriciousness and inconstancy and the other under its derision for disappointed aspirations, thereby subjecting them both to excruciating misery.” She paused and saw, with hardly concealed indignation, that he listened as though utterly devoid of remorse.

literary.text: His attachment excited gratitude, his general character respect: but she could not approve him; nor could she for a moment repent her refusal, or feel the slightest inclination ever to see him again.
paraphrases: His attachment inspired gratitude and his overall character commanded respect; yet she could not approve of him, nor could she for a moment lament her refusal or feel the slightest inclination to see him again.

His devotion aroused thankfulness and his general disposition earned respect, but she remained unable to endorse him, and she neither regretted her rejection for an instant nor harboured any desire to meet him again.

She was grateful for his unwavering attachment and held his character in high esteem; however, she could not approve him, nor would she ever repent her refusal or experience even the faintest wish to encounter him again.

literary.text: They had just been preparing to walk as the letters came in; and her uncle and aunt, leaving her to enjoy them in quiet, set off by themselves.
paraphrases: They were just getting ready for a walk when the letters arrived, and her uncle and aunt, leaving her to read them in peace, departed on their own.
Just as they were about to set off for a stroll, the letters came in; her uncle and aunt, after leaving her to enjoy them quietly, went off by themselves.
They had barely begun to prepare for a walk when the letters arrived, and her uncle and aunt, having left her to savor them in silence, set out together.

literary.text: He had seen me several times, and had intended to call on me long before, but a peculiar combination of circumstances had prevented it—signed Jay Gatsby, in a majestic hand.
paraphrases: He’d glimpsed me on numerous occasions and had meant to visit me much earlier, yet an odd twist of events kept him from doing so—signed Jay Gatsby, in a grand script.
He had observed me multiple times and planned to call upon me long ago, but an unusual set of circumstances stood in his way—signed Jay Gatsby, in a splendid hand.
He had noticed me several times and had aimed to pay me a visit sooner, though a strange convergence of circumstances prevented him—signed Jay Gatsby, in an imposing hand.

literary.text: When the tea things were removed, and the card tables placed, the ladies all rose; and Elizabeth was then hoping to be soon joined by him, when all her views were overthrown, by seeing him fall a victim to her mother’s rapacity for whist players, and in a few moments after seated with the rest of the party.
paraphrases: Once the tea service had been cleared away and the card tables arranged, all the ladies stood; Elizabeth then anticipated his soon arrival, but her hopes were dashed when she saw him succumb to her mother’s eagerness for whist enthusiasts and, moments later, take his seat among the other guests.

After the tea-cups were removed and the card tables set up, the ladies rose to their feet; Elizabeth looked forward to his joining her, until she beheld him ensnared by her mother’s voracious appetite for players of whist, and a little while later found him seated with the company.

With the tea equipage cleared away and the card tables in place, all the ladies rose, and Elizabeth expected him shortly at her side, but her expectations were shattered when she observed him falling victim to her mother’s rapacity for whist players, and soon afterward he sat down with the rest of the party.

literary.text: However, that was my fault, for he was one of those who used to sneer most bitterly at Gatsby on the courage of Gatsby’s liquor, and I should have known better than to call him.
paraphrases: That was my own fault, for he had always been one to sneer at Gatsby’s courage as nothing more than the result of his liquor, and I should have known better than to call on him.
However, it was my mistake, since he was among those who bitterly mocked Gatsby’s boldness—dismissing it as the effect of his drinking—and I ought to have known not to summon him.
But I was to blame, for he was one of the harshest critics of Gatsby’s bravery, attributing it entirely to his liquor, and I should have realized I shouldn’t have involved him.

literary.text: Elizabeth, immediately recognizing the livery, guessed what it meant, and imparted no small degree of surprise to her relations, by acquainting them with the honour which she expected.
paraphrases: Elizabeth, on instantly discerning the livery, grasped its significance and astonished her relations by acquainting them with the honour she expected.
The moment Elizabeth noticed the livery, she comprehended its meaning and amazed her relatives by disclosing the honour she anticipated.
Upon immediately identifying the livery, Elizabeth divined its import and left her relations quite surprised when she told them of the honour she expected.

literary.text: I began to like New York, the racy, adventurous feel of it at night, and the satisfaction that the constant flicker of men and women and machines gives to the restless eye.
paraphrases: I grew fond of New York, savoring its daring, adventurous atmosphere at night and the satisfaction the constant twinkle of people and machines brings to a restless gaze.
I found myself drawn to New York—the exhilarating, nocturnal energy that courses through it and the delight the ceaseless play of men, women, and machinery offers to an uneasy eye.
I came to appreciate New York, with its racy, adventurous night-time vibe and the pleasure the endless flicker of crowds and engines provides for a fidgety viewer.

literary.text: “My dear Eliza, he must be in love with you, or he would never have called on us in this familiar way.” But when Elizabeth told of his silence, it did not seem very likely, even to Charlotte’s wishes, to be the case; and, after various conjectures, they could at last only suppose his visit to proceed from the difficulty of finding anything to do, which was the more probable from the time of year.
paraphrases: Charlotte declared that he must be in love with Eliza, since he would not otherwise have visited them so familiarly, yet when Elizabeth described his continued silence even Charlotte’s hopes waned, and after various speculations they finally concluded that his only motive was a lack of anything better to occupy him at that time of year.

Charlotte insisted that Darcy’s friendly call must indicate his affection for Eliza, but upon learning of his reserve this seemed unlikely even to her, and after many conjectures they could only suppose that he visited merely out of idleness, which the season most easily permitted.

Charlotte first assumed that such a familiar visit proved Darcy’s love for Eliza, but when Elizabeth reported his silence, that belief faltered, and after pondering several possibilities they ultimately decided that his sole reason for calling was simply having nothing more interesting to engage him at that time of year.

literary.text: Charlotte’s first letters were received with a good deal of eagerness: there could not but be curiosity to know how she would speak of her new home, how she would like Lady Catherine, and how happy she would dare pronounce herself to be; though, when the letters were read, Elizabeth felt that Charlotte expressed herself on every point exactly as she might have foreseen.
paraphrases: Charlotte’s initial letters arrived amid considerable anticipation, for everyone was eager to learn how she described her new residence, what impressions she formed of Lady Catherine, and how content she dared claim to be; yet upon reading them, Elizabeth found that Charlotte’s words were exactly what she had expected.

Charlotte’s first correspondence was met with much impatience, driven by curiosity about her views on her new home, her assessment of Lady Catherine, and the degree of her happiness; however, when the letters were finally read, Elizabeth realized that Charlotte had expressed precisely what she had foreseen.

Upon arrival, Charlotte’s opening letters stirred great excitement—there was a strong desire to hear her account of her new abode, her opinion of Lady Catherine, and how happy she professed to feel; still, when Elizabeth perused the letters, she observed that Charlotte’s remarks aligned perfectly with her own predictions.

literary.text: She immediately felt that whatever desire Miss Darcy might have of being acquainted with her, must be the work of her brother, and without looking farther, it was satisfactory; it was gratifying to know that his resentment had not made him think really ill of her.
paraphrases: She instantly perceived that any wish Miss Darcy had to become acquainted with her must have been her brother’s doing, and without further deliberation she was satisfied; it was gratifying to know his resentment had not turned him against her.

She immediately concluded that Miss Darcy’s interest in meeting her must have originated with her brother, and without seeking other reasons she felt content; it pleased her that his anger hadn’t made him really think ill of her.

She at once recognized that any eagerness Miss Darcy showed to know her must be traced back to her brother, and she was quickly reassured; she found it comforting that his resentment had not led him to view her unfavorably.

literary.text: Well, I was so frightened I did not know what to do, for my uncle was to give me away; and if we were beyond the hour we could not be married all day.
paraphrases: I was so terrified I didn’t know what to do, for my uncle was to give me away; and if we were past the hour, we could not be married until the next day.
Overwhelmed by fear, I didn’t know what to do, since my uncle was meant to give me away, and missing the appointed hour meant we couldn’t wed that day.
I was so alarmed I was at a loss, for my uncle was to give me away; and if we exceeded the set time, our marriage would have to wait until the following day.

literary.text: Her Ladyship received them civilly, but it was plain that their company was by no means so acceptable as when she could get nobody else; and she was, in fact, almost engrossed by her nephews, speaking to them, especially to Darcy, much more than to any other person in the room.
paraphrases: Lady Catherine welcomed them courteously, yet it was obvious that she preferred their company far less than when she had no one else to entertain; indeed, she was almost entirely absorbed by her nephews, speaking to them—especially Darcy—much more than to anyone else in the room.

Her Ladyship received them with politeness, but it was plain that their presence was nowhere near as enjoyable as when she had no other guests; in fact, she was nearly monopolized by her nephews, addressing them, and Darcy in particular, far more than any other person around.

She entertained them civilly, though it was evident their company was considerably less preferable than having no one else; she was truly engrossed by her nephews, conversing with them—Darcy above all—significantly more than with any other attendee.

literary.text: Perhaps Daisy never went in for amour at all—and yet there’s something in that voice of hers … Well, about six weeks ago, she heard the name Gatsby for the first time in years.
paraphrases: Perhaps Daisy was never keen on love—and yet there’s a certain resonance in her voice … Well, around six weeks ago, she heard Gatsby’s name for the first time in years.
Maybe Daisy never cared for romance at all—but there’s a peculiar note in her tone … Six weeks ago or so, she heard the name Gatsby again after years.
Possibly Daisy never dabbled in amour—and yet the sound of her voice hints at something … About six weeks back, she encountered the name Gatsby after years of absence.

literary.text: “After that I lived like a young rajah in all the capitals of Europe—Paris, Venice, Rome—collecting jewels, chiefly rubies, hunting big game, painting a little, things for myself only, and trying to forget something very sad that had happened to me long ago.” With an effort I managed to restrain my incredulous laughter.
paraphrases: Later I lived like a young maharajah in the great capitals of Europe—Paris, Venice, Rome—amassing jewels, mostly rubies, hunting big game, dabbling in painting for my own pleasure, and striving to banish a long-buried sorrow. With effort, I repressed my incredulous laughter.

From then on I enjoyed a rajah’s existence across Europe’s principal cities—Paris, Venice, Rome—collecting precious stones (chiefly rubies), embarking on big-game hunts, doing a little painting, indulging only myself, and endeavoring to forget a profound sadness from the past. I managed, with some difficulty, to stifle my disbelieving laughter.

Thereafter I lived as though I were a youthful prince in the capitals of Europe—Paris, Venice, Rome—gathering jewels, especially rubies, pursuing large-game hunts, painting occasionally, solely catering to my own desires, and attempting to erase a deep old sorrow. I forced myself, with effort, to contain my incredulous laughter.

literary.text: I am going to Gretna Green, and if you cannot guess with who, I shall think you a simpleton, for there is but one man in the world I love, and he is an angel.
paraphrases: I'm headed for Gretna Green, and should you fail to divine my companion, I'll deem you a simpleton, for there's but one man in the world I love, and he is an angel.
I'm bound for Gretna Green, and if you can't guess who goes with me, I'll regard you as a simpleton, since there's only one man I love in all the world, and he is an angel.
I'm traveling to Gretna Green, and if you don't know who accompanies me, I'll consider you a simpleton; there's but one man I love on earth, and he is an angel.

literary.text: Mrs. Bennet’s eyes sparkled with pleasure, and she was eagerly calling out, while her daughter read,-- “Well, Jane, who is it from?
paraphrases: Mrs. Bennet’s eyes gleamed with pleasure as she called out eagerly while her daughter perused the letter, “Well, Jane, who is it from?”
Her eyes sparkling with delight, Mrs. Bennet cried out with impatient curiosity while her daughter read, “So, Jane, who has sent it?”
With her eyes shining in pleasure, Mrs. Bennet exclaimed eagerly as her daughter read, “Pray tell, Jane, who has sent it?”

literary.text: The officers may not be so pleasant in General----’s regiment.” His daughter’s request, for such it might be considered, of being admitted into her family again, before she set off for the north, received at first an absolute negative.
paraphrases: The officers in General----’s regiment may not prove particularly agreeable. His daughter’s plea—if indeed that is what it amounted to—to be readmitted into her family before setting off northward was initially met with an absolute refusal.

In General----’s regiment the officers might not be so affable. When his daughter made her request—if such it could be called—to rejoin her family before undertaking her journey north, she was first met with a firm no.
The officers under General----’s command may lack pleasantness. His daughter’s appeal—if one could term it that—to return to her family before heading northward was at first rejected outright.

literary.text: Nobody wants him to come; though I shall always say that he used my daughter extremely ill; and, if I was her, I would not have put up with it.
paraphrases: No one wants him to come; yet I shall always maintain he treated my daughter exceedingly ill; and, had I been in her stead, I would not have endured it.
Nobody desires his arrival; though I shall always assert he behaved very badly toward my daughter; and if I were her, I would not have put up with such treatment.
Everybody rejects his coming; nevertheless, I shall ever say he treated my daughter extremely ill; and, had I been her, I would not have borne it.

literary.text: He was writing, and, without raising his head, coolly replied,-- “Just as you please.” “May we take my uncle’s letter to read to her?” “Take whatever you like, and get away.” Elizabeth took the letter from his writing-table, and they went upstairs together.
paraphrases: He continued his writing without lifting his head and coolly replied, “Just as you please.” When they asked, “May we take my uncle’s letter to read to her?” he said, “Help yourselves and be gone.” Elizabeth took the letter from his writing-table, and they went upstairs together.

Still bent over his work, he coldly answered, “Do as you wish.” At the question, “May we take my uncle’s letter to read to her?” he curtly responded, “Take whatever you like and leave.” Elizabeth retrieved the letter from his writing-table, and they ascended the stairs together.

Writing on without raising his gaze, he remarked coolly, “Whatever you like.” When they inquired, “Can we take my uncle’s letter to show her?” he dryly replied, “Take anything you wish and be gone.” Elizabeth picked up the letter from his writing-table, and they proceeded upstairs together.

literary.text: He had not a temper to bear the sort of competition in which we stood--the sort of preference which was often given me.” “I had not thought Mr. Darcy so bad as this--though I have never liked him, I had not thought so very ill of him--I had supposed him to be despising his fellow-creatures in general, but did not suspect him of descending to such malicious revenge, such injustice, such inhumanity as this!” After a few minutes’ reflection, however, she continued, “I _do_ remember his boasting one day, at Netherfield, of the implacability of his resentments, of his having an unforgiving temper.
paraphrases: He lacked the disposition to endure the kind of rivalry we faced or the kind of favour so often shown to me, and although I had never cared for Mr. Darcy, I never believed him capable of such vindictive cruelty, injustice, and inhumanity—only that he generally scorned his fellow creatures—until I recalled his proud boast at Netherfield about the implacability of his resentments and his unforgiving temper.

She realized he wasn’t cut out for the competition in which we stood or the preference I frequently received, and despite my dislike of Mr. Darcy, I had never thought him capable of malicious revenge and gross injustice—merely of general disdain—until I remembered his Netherfield brag about nursing grudges without forgiveness.

It struck her that he simply did not possess the temperament to bear the sort of rivalry we endured or the preference often granted to me, and though I had always disliked Mr. Darcy, I had never imagined him capable of such inhuman malice and injustice—only a general contempt for others—until recalling his boast at Netherfield of his unforgiving resentments.

literary.text: Sometimes, in my mind, I followed them to their apartments on the corners of hidden streets, and they turned and smiled back at me before they faded through a door into warm darkness.
paraphrases: At times, in my imagination, I trailed them to their flats nestled at the corners of secret alleys, and they looked over their shoulders and returned my smile before slipping through a doorway into welcoming gloom.

Occasionally, within my thoughts, I followed them down hidden lane turns to their apartments tucked around obscure corners, and they turned back and smiled at me just before vanishing behind a door into soft darkness.

Now and then, in my mind’s eye, I shadowed them to their residences perched on the bends of concealed streets, and they glanced back with a smile before disappearing through a door into gentle darkness.

literary.text: Do clear _them_, too, or we shall be obliged to think ill of somebody.” “Laugh as much as you choose, but you will not laugh me out of my opinion.
paraphrases: Make sure to clear them too, or we’ll be forced to suspect someone. Laugh as much as you like, but you won’t persuade me to alter my opinion.
Clear those as well, or we shall have no choice but to suspect someone. Go ahead and laugh all you want, yet your laughter won’t dislodge my belief.
You must clear them too, otherwise we’ll be compelled to think ill of someone. Laugh to your heart’s content, but you won’t sway my judgment.

literary.text: If I was them I’d get a divorce and get married to each other right away.” “Doesn’t she like Wilson either?” The answer to this was unexpected.
paraphrases: “If I were in their shoes, I’d get a divorce and tie the knot with each other right away.” “She isn’t fond of Wilson either?” The answer caught me by surprise.
“If I’d been them, I’d file for divorce and marry one another immediately.” “She doesn’t care for Wilson either?” The reply was totally unexpected.
“Had I been in their place, I’d end my marriage and wed each other at once.” “She’s not into Wilson either?” What came next was astonishing.

literary.text: In his library he had been always sure of leisure and tranquillity; and though prepared, as he told Elizabeth, to meet with folly and conceit in every other room in the house, he was used to be free from them there: his civility, therefore, was most prompt in inviting Mr. Collins to join his daughters in their walk; and Mr. Collins, being in fact much better fitted for a walker than a reader, was extremely well pleased to close his large book, and go.
paraphrases: In his library he always enjoyed leisure and tranquillity; and although, as he told Elizabeth, he expected to find folly and conceit in every other room, he was accustomed to be free of them there; hence his civility was most prompt in inviting Mr. Collins to join his daughters on their walk, and Mr. Collins, far better suited to walking than reading, was extremely pleased to close his large book and go.

He always found his library a sanctuary of calm and leisure; and though he warned Elizabeth that in every other chamber he might meet with folly and conceit, he never encountered them there; thus he politely and promptly invited Mr. Collins to accompany his daughters on their walk, and Mr. Collins, being much more of a walker than a reader, was delighted to set aside his ponderous volume and join them.

In his library he was ever assured of peace and leisure; and while, as he confessed to Elizabeth, he was prepared to encounter folly and conceit throughout the rest of the house, that room remained free of them; accordingly, he was most ready in his civility to ask Mr. Collins to walk with his daughters, and Mr. Collins, decidedly a walker rather than a reader, was highly pleased to close his large book and go.

literary.text: Tell your chauffeur to go far away and spend an hour.” “Come back in an hour, Ferdie.” Then in a grave murmur: “His name is Ferdie.” “Does the gasoline affect his nose?” “I don’t think so,” she said innocently.
paraphrases: “Ask your chauffeur to drive far away and linger for an hour,” she said. “Come back in an hour, Ferdie.” Then in a grave murmur: “His name’s Ferdie.” “Might the gasoline bother his nose?” “I don’t think it does,” she answered innocently.

“Tell your driver to go off somewhere distant and stay put for an hour,” she instructed. “Return in an hour, Ferdie.” In a low, solemn voice she added, “He’s called Ferdie.” “Will the fuel upset his nose?” “I doubt it,” she said sweetly.

“Request your chauffeur to head well away and wait an hour,” she directed. “Be back in an hour, Ferdie.” Then softly, in a solemn tone: “His name happens to be Ferdie.” “Does the petrol hurt his sense of smell?” “I don’t think so,” she responded innocently.

literary.text: Many circumstances might make it more eligible for them to be married privately in town than to pursue their first plan; and even if _he_ could form such a design against a young woman of Lydia’s connections, which is not likely, can I suppose her so lost to everything?
paraphrases: Numerous factors could render a private marriage in town more advisable than their original scheme; and even if he were capable of contriving such a plot against a young lady of Lydia’s standing, which is improbable, can I truly believe her so devoid of all propriety?

Various conditions might render it more prudent for them to wed quietly in town rather than stick to their initial plan; and even should he entertain such a stratagem toward a young woman of Lydia’s rank, which is unlikely, am I to think her utterly without virtue?

A variety of circumstances could make a discreet town wedding more fitting for them than their first intention; and even if he were to devise such a scheme against a young woman with Lydia’s connections, which seems improbable, can I imagine her completely abandoned of all sense?

literary.text: Lady Lucas could not be insensible of triumph on being able to retort on Mrs. Bennet the comfort of having a daughter well married; and she called at Longbourn rather oftener than usual to say how happy she was, though Mrs. Bennet’s sour looks and ill-natured remarks might have been enough to drive happiness away.
paraphrases: Lady Lucas could hardly conceal her sense of triumph in reminding Mrs. Bennet of the pleasure in having a well-married daughter, and she dropped by Longbourn more often than usual to proclaim her joy, even though Mrs. Bennet’s frowns and ill-natured comments were enough to dispel her happiness.

Lady Lucas felt a keen sense of victory as she retorted to Mrs. Bennet with the comfort of a happily wedded daughter, and she called at Longbourn more frequently than before to declare her delight, despite Mrs. Bennet’s sour visage and spiteful remarks that might have tainted her cheer.

Lady Lucas could not hide her triumph when she answered Mrs. Bennet with the reassurance of a well-married daughter, and she visited Longbourn more often than customary to celebrate her contentment, though Mrs. Bennet’s sullen looks and cutting observations threatened to drive that joy away.

literary.text: _You_ think it a faithful portrait, undoubtedly.” “I must not decide on my own performance.” He made no answer; and they were again silent till they had gone down the dance, when he asked her if she and her sisters did not very often walk to Meryton.
paraphrases: “Indeed, you regard it as a faithful likeness.” “I must not judge the quality of my own performance.” He offered no response, and they sat in silence until the dance concluded, when he asked whether she and her sisters did not frequently walk to Meryton.

“Undoubtedly, you find it an accurate portrayal.” “It is not for me to assess my own execution.” No answer came from him, and they remained quiet until the dance ended; afterward, he inquired if she and her sisters often walked to Meryton.

“You certainly think it a true representation.” “I ought not to settle on my own rendition.” He made no reply, and they kept silent until the conclusion of the dance, then he asked if she and her sisters regularly went on foot to Meryton.

literary.text: It would look odd to be entirely silent for half an hour together; and yet, for the advantage of _some_, conversation ought to be so arranged as that they may have the trouble of saying as little as possible.” “Are you consulting your own feelings in the present case, or do you imagine that you are gratifying mine?” “Both,” replied Elizabeth archly; “for I have always seen a great similarity in the turn of our minds.
paraphrases: It would seem strange to sit in complete silence for half an hour, and yet, for the benefit of some, our conversation should be so arranged that they are burdened with speaking as little as possible; “Are you appealing to your own feelings here, or do you imagine you are catering to mine?” “Both,” replied Elizabeth archly; “for I have always observed a remarkable likeness in the direction of our minds.”

It might feel odd to endure thirty minutes without a word, and still, for the advantage of a few, discourse must be managed so that they have the trouble of uttering as little as they can; “Are you consulting your own emotions now, or do you suppose you are gratifying mine?” “Both,” answered Elizabeth with a mischievous air; “for I have long perceived a great similarity between our minds.”

Total silence for half an hour would appear peculiar; nevertheless, for the sake of certain persons, conversation ought to be so arranged that they are inconvenienced by having to speak as little as possible—“Are you addressing your own inclinations at present, or do you fancy you are indulging mine?” “Both,” replied Elizabeth archly; “for I have always found our minds to be very much alike.”

literary.text: His father, Miss Bennet, the late Mr. Darcy, was one of the best men that ever breathed, and the truest friend I ever had; and I can never be in company with this Mr. Darcy without being grieved to the soul by a thousand tender recollections.
paraphrases: Miss Bennet, his father, the late Mr. Darcy, was one of the finest men who ever lived and the most faithful friend I ever possessed, and I cannot endure being in Mr. Darcy’s company without my soul being torn by a thousand tender memories.
Miss Bennet, his father, the late Mr. Darcy, was among the most excellent of men and my truest friend, and every meeting with Mr. Darcy now fills me with agonizingly sweet remembrances.

Miss Bennet, his father, the late Mr. Darcy, ranked as one of the best men to ever breathe and as my dearest friend, and to see Mr. Darcy again is to feel my heart pained by innumerable affectionate recollections.

literary.text: I remember the fur coats of the girls returning from Miss This-or-That’s and the chatter of frozen breath and the hands waving overhead as we caught sight of old acquaintances, and the matchings of invitations: “Are you going to the Ordways’?
paraphrases: I recall the girls in fur coats returning from Miss This-or-That’s, their frosty breaths chattering, hands waving above as we spotted old acquaintances, followed by the volley of invitations: “Are you going to the Ordways’?”

I can still picture fur-clad girls coming back from Miss This-or-That’s, their frozen breaths hissing in the cold while they waved to familiar faces, and the back-and-forth of invites: “Will you be at the Ordways’?”

academic.text: The Transformer allows for significantly more parallelization and can reach a new state of the art in translation quality after being trained for as little as twelve hours on eight P100 GPUs.The goal of reducing sequential computation also forms the foundation of the Extended Neural GPU [16], ByteNet [18] and ConvS2S [9], all of which use convolutional neural networks as basic building block, computing hidden representations in parallel for all input and output positions.
